It's in the Umfurudzi NP, so you have to pay entrance fees: 
5 USD pppn, 9 USD for your car.
4*4 required, not possible for big rigs!
Unexpected sightings of giraffe and zebra at the other bank of the river!

name: Usanga Camp
description:
Big sign to Usanga Camp, run by Zimbabwe Wildlife Management Authority, at the main road.
But, they don't have any accommodation!
However, they let us camp behind their building, and use the toilet and (cold) shower for free.
Unfortunately, the place is infested with Mopane flies!

name: Trek Petroleum
description: Diesel for $1,35 and only petro station in Bulawaio that accepted Credit card!!!(we have tryed maybe other 10 places).

name: Ubuntu
description: Brand new Hostel run by Christa (from Germany) and Takunda.  Very cosy, nicely decorated with art and beautiful details. Dorms are $15 pp and rooms from $30 and $40. You can use the kitchen and wifi, there's space for 2 cars on the garage for camping (regular garage). You can also order drinks and some delicious homemade meals. Everything is new and comfortable and Takunda is a local guide and can give you the best tips for walking around (amazing sunset and mountains). You can call him ahead if you would like to book it +263 777124064. Pay with cash or online.

name: Sikato Lion Park Official Campsite
description: Well maintained campsite located by the lake with nice views. Tap water, braai and picnic tables at each spots. Nice vegetation and trees around. Clean ablution blocks with flush toilets and showers (no hot water when we were here).  Econet internet signal is slow at campsite but works great near reception gate. You can walk to see the lions enclosure if you're into it but we came just to camp by the lake. We took a pleasant walk through the forest following some car tracks. No swimming as there are hippos and crocodiles in the lake. Camping rate for internationals: 8 USD ppn. Zimbabwens pay 5 USD ppn. No park fees.

name: Nyuni Mountain Lodge (Reception)
description: We didn't stay but they offer camping here with toilets and cold showers. You can use a chalet for hot showers if needed. They have a huge property and I'm sure you can camp anywhere you want. They asked for 7,50 USD ppn, probably negotiable. No internet connection with Econet.

name: Standard Chartered Bank ATM
description: Here you can get US$ straight out of the ATM. Maximum was 900US $ per withdrawal. We used VISA.

name: Econet Shop
description:
You can buy a SIM card here. Costs 1 US$. And you get airtime and internet bundles as well. You need your passport for registration.
Well organized place.

name: Zuva Gas
description: Right at the filling station. Refilled our South African CADAC gas bottle. Paid 3 USD for 1,2kg.

name: Econet internet signal
description: Only place in the park (from Sinamantella to Ngweshla Campsite) where we had some Econet signal for internet. Around Main Camp it also works a bit.

name: Kanyemba Falcon Lodges
description:
Big lodge and campsite at the Zambezi River, in a quiet setting.
No ZIM telephone coverage, only from Zambia. 
No restaurant, you need to bring your own food.
Camping 10 USD pppn, chalets 20 USD pppn. We negotiated the chalet down to 15 USD pppn (without receipt).
Good value for money. Chalets have a fully equipped kitchen, with a big gas stove.
Solar for light only. They might run the generator for the socket outlets in the evening, if they have fuel!
Good alternative to Chinembi Fishing camp! Good access road.
Hippos and monkeys around.
There is no shortcut to Mana Pools! You have to drive all the way back to Angwa Bridge (on a bad road)!

name: Chevilla Falls
description: nice view point on falls when the Runde River meet red rocks.

name: Tiger Safaris Lodge
description: Excellent spot to camp before or after crossing the border. We stayed two nights in a riverside self catering cottage for 48USD per person, very clean, friendly and attentive staff, helpful owners. Campsite is also on the river bank with very clean ablutions, 15 USD per person. Bar and restaurant. Phone +263 778020699 / www.tigersafaris.co.zw

name: Ngamla Cycles
description: Bicycle repair workshop run by a guy named Presson. They seem to know what they're doing and have a decent collection of quality spare parts for bicycles.

name: Bulawayo, Hillside Dams Conservancy
description:
It is more a recreational park, but they have a small camping section on the east side of the Lower Dam (with ablutions), but that part is not accessible for big rigs.
We were therefore offered to stay along the park road, directly adjacent to the greens.
Very pleasant atmosphere, very friendly staff, dead quiet at night
Not in walking distance to the city centre.
Entrance fee USD2/pp (pensioner $1), camping $5/pp, vehicle $1

name: Bulawayo and District Publicity Association
description: Local tourist information centre for the city and surrounding area.  Very friendly, helpful and informative.  Open 08.30 to 16.30 Monday to Friday.

name: between Road and Diana
description:
a place for one overnight.
quiet
Well hidden, at 1km from the road, behind the rocks
well 
The shepherds pass early in the morning but no problem
network econet ok

name: Immigration in Bulawayo
description:
Visa extension
in less then 5 minutes!
Fastest ever!

name: Customs House Bulawayo
description:
The place to extend your TIP, insurance and carbon tax.
Very unfriendly, for Zimbabwe standards!

name: Camp Silwane
description:
Very nice campsite, just outside the park.
Behind the railway line, just outside Kennedy Gate, opposite Hide Camp inside the park.
35 USD for up to 4 people.
Hot bucket shower, flush toilet, both open to the stars, brai area, fire wood included!
No electricity, but an absolutely brilliant night sky!
Lenmo, the very friendly caretaker, keeps the site and your private ablutions speckless clean.
He will prepare hot water, and start your fire.
He will also help you setting up your tent, and washing your dishes, so basically, he will be your personal butler!
I don't think the last two items are included in his job description, so I think it's appropriate to give him a tip at the end!
There is a waterhole near the campsite, and there were plenty of animal tracks and elephant dung on the campsite, but we didn't see any animals around when we were there.
You need to enter the park at Main Camp in order to pay the park entrance fees, and leave through Kennedy Gate. No payments at Kennedy Gate!
Latest entry through Main Gate at 16:00, you need to leave through Kennedy at 18:00!
You need to pay park fees for the first and last day (and of course for the days in between), no free transit!

name: EcoNet
description: Bought and registered our Zim Sim card here

name: EcoNet Karoi
description: Top up vouchers and Sim registration. Next to TOTAL.

name: Geoff's Camp
description:
Big rig friendly. We parked on a slab from the old house at this location. Nice view to the river below. We could not reach the gorge view campsites (trees).

Ablutions block even has a view - three sides with one open to the gorge.

It's a tricky drive in for a 11T truck, but doable with some tree brushing.

name: Mucheni Gorge Viewpoint
description:
Viewpoint of the gorge. Reachable through a quite overgrown 2 track. No facilities whatsoever, but nice and flat with some hard clay to park on. They allowed us to camp here when the 2 official campsites on the gorge were full. You have a view down towards Lake Kariba in the distance and into the beginning of the gorge; you are really on the point of the mountain.

Nice sunset AND sunrise, very quiet at night.

name: Clearing in the bush, formerly a road works site
description:
Along the M15 coming from Makuti, right after the hairpin to the right. Some high grass but no problem to access, quite wide and flat. Was a construction site for road works, now abandoned.
Bushes, trees and high grass give good sight protection, so even big rigs can hardly be seen from the road.
After nightfall, virtually no traffic anymore, we were not disturbed in any way and spent a very quiet night.

name: Ethandweni Children's Home
description: A lovely orphanage with about 40 kids of different ages. We had the feeling that it's really well organised and the kids can be very happy to have found a new home here. We had a really nice and interesting visit here! According to the friendly owner Lucien and the lovely "Mamas", visitors are always welcome to pop in. They also sell their own grown veggies, lemons and eggs.

name: Mana Pools Chitake Camp Site 1
description:
Chitake Campsite 1 is a lovely sandy spot literally next to a riverbed of which the source is apparently a spring (but in June it looks more like a mostly dry riverbed with a slight trickle). It's a beautiful spot, on a flat patch of sand. It's an elephant highway, the riverbed, calm elephants going up and down. Also many relaxed baboons (wild, they leave you alone) and saw Black backed jackal and Spotted hyena drinking at night. We heard lions further south but didn't see them.

We actually booked Chitake 2 but that's a farce of a campsite, in the middle of shrub, overgrown, no view anywhere around, and we were hoping to see the lions at that spot as everyone keeps saying it is dangerous lion territory up there, but did not even see tracks, so we went for the much more beautiful Chitake 1 instead. Amazingly quiet at night except for nature sounds.

Bring everything yourself as if wild camping. There is only a pit toilet.

name: Spar Bridge
description: LPG fill station in the Spar carpark. Filled my CADAC bottle here.

name: Surry Supermarket and Exceptional Pies
description:
Small supermarket selling farm produce, meat and beer. The pies are exceptional: packed full of your chosen filling eg Steak and Kidney or Beef and Onion. Sold hot or frozen. $2.50 each.
Easy parking.

name: Mutare Club
description:
An old colonial club open to vistors for meals and accommodation. Access to bar area is for members only.

Very nostalgic building with historical pictures on the walls. Gives one a glance of what life once was in the old days.

Very friendly staff, good food and reasonable prices

name: Pork Pie Observation Point
description:
Its in the park (but there was nobody around) and visiting hours are day time only. Big Rig friendly - we climbed up in our 11T truck.  Amazing 360° view!!
The sunset and sunrise were very special from here.

name: View Over Lake
description: Adjacent to road on a rock plateau over looking the lake with the sunset over it.  In sight of road and there are villagers coming and going. School kids were fascinated by our truck. Very few cars after dark. Undisturbed night.

name: Umzingwane Dam Campground
description: Campsite is on the banks of the reservoir with nice views (but water was low during our visit). Its NP run, so run down. Long drop toilet, not clean. No shower. OK for self-contained vehicles. Big rig friendly. There are plans to improve.

name: The Bulawayo Club (est. 1896)
description:
This place is a time machine, taking you back to the colonial days.  It is an gentleman's club from a bygone era that is somehow still hanging on. We stayed two nights. The rooms are clean, comfortable and with ensuite bathrooms.
We had a really good evening meal (G&Ts to start, starter and main meal with wine and beer) and it came to $33. Breakfast is limited to a  Full English. Very reasonable. It will take few hours to explore all the nooks and crannies, looking at the sculptures and old artwork. The elevator is a museum piece  itself (and is still working). We manged to squeeze our 11T MAN into the secure parking at the rear.

name: ATM
description: ATM where you can get US dollars, 8$ fee.

name: KWEZA LODGE
description: Very nice! Clean, new linen and kitchen appliances. Fireplace, DSTV, WiFi, Netflix. The best we saw as far as lodges go (or anything goes) in Chimanimani. It was raining so we couldn’t camp and this was the perfect place! 20usd ppn for the twin rims (of which there are 3 downstairs) or 30usd ppn for the upstairs double room with en-suite. Highly recommend this place. Timothy is your host, he will sort you out with firewood!

name: Plot 121 John Galt Village
description:
We wanted to camp but it was raining, so we opted to stay here, the same owner owns Kweza Lodge in Chimanimani. It’s a big house in a wildlife estate, with a fireplace, one king size bed, other rooms are twin beds. At the time there was no WiFi (but we’re told it was going to be out in). Clean and renovated. 

It would have been nice if we had time to spend more than a night here! 

Apologies for slightly incorrect location as we had already left the premesis.

Here is the google maps link:
https://goo.gl/maps/fZSgUL1RMizFvfi56

The housekeeper Felisitas was very helpful.

$20ppn

name: middy's coffee shop
description:
we tried a few coffees in town but we liked this place the most. There is a fireplace when its cold and the Cappucchino and Latte was delicious. 

They also have free WiFi and a good food menu.

name: Refugees camp
description: Refugees camp at the border. They will let you pitch your tent. They gave me an empty room for the night. It was dirty but I pitched my tent inside. Toilets are available.

name: China garden
description:
many good meals around 5$. noodle and soup. fried rice. My favorite of so far two meals was the spicy pulled noodles soup (S1 on the extensive menu). 
free green tea. had a really friendly chap serving me. Good free wifi. Three different seating areas with different feelings. Sitting toilet for the gents. 
Stayed here for almost three hours relaxing. Terrific place!

name: Wild camping
description:
Peaceful site next to Sebakwe dam. Much better than the official camp site. Game across the bay and very little wind.
We checked in to the official site and stayed there one night, but no water etc. etc. etc. So, tonight across the dam at this spot - much better.
Camping fees USD40 for two people for two nights, inclusive of vehicle entry and conservation fee.

name: Mazowe Dam Wild Camp
description:
We turned right a short distance after the dam wall and followed the dirt road (using google apps satellite view) to the opposite side of the dam, furtherest from the main road and found a beautiful spot in between two trees, the grass in this area had been grazed short by the cattle so it’s perfect. We sipped our G&T’s while listening to the gentle tinkling of cow bells as the sun went down between the two hills in front of us. Magnificent!

When you wild camp, It’s VERY  important that you do not leave ANY trace that you were there. This makes it possible for the next people to wild camp, as it should be - natural. Wild camping should not disturb the environment, nor the people that live nearby.

name: Angwa Mana Pools Camp
description:
Moderator note: Campsite is now closed.

NOTE THE NAME IS MISLEADING!! IT IS NOWHERE NEAR THE TOWN OF ANGWA
This is on Tracks4Africa as a camp - listed under campsites. Well… after following the route on our GPS to get here, the track eventually became impassable and we had to turn back. We picked up another road which was a proper dirt track (now it’s past sunset) to the place, pitch dark and when we arrived… it’s a broken down, abandoned place. We had to camp here as it was now 7.30pm

name: New BBC Campsite
description:
This is an exclusive campsite which already makes it awesome. There are Lots of Hippo and birds. When the sun sets you won’t get much of the clouds changing colour but eventually the river lights up beautifully. 

- Muddy if wet
- Long drop toilet without seat
- Monkeys WILL steal your food - lock up everything, all the time, even when you are here. They know how to open doors etc. 

$32pppn 
$15pppd
$20 for the vehicle

name: Outward Bound
description:
Outward Bound offers adventure classes for all ages, with a focus to empower the youth.
Jo and his family were very welcoming to let us stay on their grounds on a donation basis, which includes great vista, hot shower and bathroom, and of course the visit to Tessa's Pool. Intermittent econet cell service. There are 5 friendly young dog on the grounds. 

Jo mentioned that they can also offer customized outdoor classes, which they can arrange on the spot and without prior notice. This would be at a cost of $25 pppd and would include 2 activities. These could be anything ziplining, abseiling, mountain climbing, river crossing, etc. We were on a set schedule and didn't take any.

name: Wild Camp
description:
A nice open, flat hard surfaced ground not too far off the road. There are a lot of elephants in the area and this offered a safe spot to overnight. Only two cars passed us in the night and some fellow adventurers the next morning. 

When you wild camp, It’s VERY  important that you do not leave ANY trace that you were there. This makes it possible for the next people to wild camp, as it should be - natural. Wild camping should not disturb the environment, animals or the people that live nearby.

name: Gache Gache Campsite
description:
So sad to see howCovid has destroyed businesses!! The campsite is now very run down (and the lodge has seen better days), they have no water at the campsite but offered to open a chalet for use (but the chalets are far from the campsite so would have to camp where the chalets are if you need water).
If you’re self-sufficient, the one campsite has a nice view of the lake and is a short walk to the water's edge should you wish to fish. The manager was very friendly and said we could camp there for $5ppn as there’s no water and he “didn’t want to rob us”

name: Abandoned community Cattle Dip
description: Perfect spot at an abandoned US Aid cattle dip facility. Has a flat concrete foundation next to a big tree, close to the river. You can walk down to the river using the cattle path / foot path. A curious and friendly local came to chat, other than that no body disturbed us. We only heard 2 cars the whole night!

name: Wild Camp
description:
A welcome clearing not too far off the road. Nice open space scattered with mopani bushes and trees. Plenty firewood laying around. There’s signs of Elephant activity here so make your fire big! But please clean it up afterwards.

When you wild camp, It’s VERY  important that you do not leave ANY trace that you were there. This makes it possible for the next people to wild camp, as it should be - natural. Wild camping should not disturb the environment, animals or the people that live nearby.

name: Lake Mutirikwi (Kyle) Rec Park Campground
description:
The official campground of the Recreational Park, offers stunning views over the lake, and the opportunity to see some 18 Rhinos the small park has to offer (minus their horns which already apparently were cut off for their protection).
As far as the campsite goes, it's falling apart. Be prepared for basically a wild camp. Water and electricity reportedly haven't worked since 2013.
$9 pppn for international visitors, plus the park fee of $10 per person or auto, comes to $48 for a vehicle with 2 adults, for a night in the park.

name: Riverside
description: Nice place along the rivers edge (not much water) for a picnic stop on your way in or out of the park to break the drive. Saw lots of curious waterbuck, an elephant and plenty of wader birds in the marsh. You have to cross a washaway

name: Immigration Masvingo
description:
Here you extend your tourist visa for another 30 days. 
It's also possible to extend your tourist visa at any ZIM border post, without leaving the country! Extensions for up to 3 month's are free, from month 4 up to month 6, 20,- USD per month.

name: Matetsi River
description:
Follow the track on the west side of the Matetsi Bridge that goes south off the A8. Follow the track for about 1km (your vehicle will get scratched as it’s bushy and narrow in some places) to the river. You can camp on either bank, we decided to cross the river as it was flatter and more grassy. Definitely no big rigs or trailers. Need a 4x4 to cross the river.
WILD CAMPING ETIQUETTE
1. GOING TO THE TOILET - Find a place where people are unlikely to walk. Dig a hole, do your business, burn the toilet paper (without causing a fire), cover the hole again. 
2. FIRES / BRAAI’s - If you have to make your fire on the ground: Dispose of the ash (without causing a fire) & cover with sand. Leave it looking as natural as you found it. 
3. Do not leave any rubbish behind. 
Wild camping should not disturb the environment, animals or the people that live nearby.

name: Totally Tyres and Mechanic
description: The owner Talent and his guys work really fast and are reliable. They can do anything related to tyres and little mechanical things like a service. They seem very knowledgeable. We had all our tyres changed here and a full service at a reasonable price. They told us they can fix motorcycles and bicycles too :) open every day 6-18. Emergency number: +263773627460

name: Mount Binga
description: Nice hike to the top of Mozambiques highest mountain. At the half way there is clean water to top up your water bottles.

name: Ngonye Falls Entrance Gate
description:
This is where you go in to meet the guide who’ll take you to the falls. 
25.50ZK per person and vehicle

name: GMC Automotive
description: Masu Chigwende finds for every problem a solution. Our Nissan Navara had a broken zylinderhead. He can find new or secondhand parts without any problems. We even could stay in our car while under repair. Very recommended for types of car. Tel. +263772668937 (WhatsApp)

name: Wild Camp
description: This was a great stop over for the night on our way to beitbridge. Enjoy 😊

name: Bush camp off A14
description: A small quarry about 100m off the road well secluded and nobody around very quiet. Great for a safe stop over. We are enroute from Nyamapanda border taking the A14 back road to the eastern highlands (don’t want to go via Harare)

name: big flat place
description: Beautiful flat big space, maybe the only one on the whole route from Chimanimani to Cashel. We hiked from here 2km along the road towards Cashel, did a right turn up to the hills and hiked along the footpath from the locals back towards Chimanimani, when we reached the road again, a right turn brought us back to the starting point. Total lenght about 6,7km with beautiful views down into the valley. You'll find the tracks on osm based maps. Weak Econet signal.

name: Jiri Camp
description:
This has camp sites @5usd ppn very overgrown but wip with 220vac power points ( currently not all working)  and 2/3  bedroom self catering fully equipped chalets , toilet, shower with fridge . Stoveplate, toaster kettle @ 10usd ppn - have to pay at Triangle Country club on arrival - nice view of dam.
Camp receives cell signal 
Contact Razimus Chikuvire

name: Birchenough Bridge
description: Nice spot with a beautiful view to the bridge. Fruit and veggie market  you'll find on the other side of the river.

name: Broken Bridge
description:
6 months ago the bridge felt down because of the amount of water 
you can not cross it anymore 
We had to turn around

name: Zuva Gas
description: Fill your gas.  Roughly US$3 per kg.  Friendly and fast service
